contentrichtext.text: {{For|the practice of wearing a kilt without undergarments|True Scotsman}} '''No true Scotsman''' is an [[informal fallacy]], an ''[[ad hoc]]'' attempt to retain an unreasoned assertion.<ref>[http://www.iep.utm.edu/fallacy/#NoTrueScotsman No True Scotsman], ''[[Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]''</ref> When faced with a [[counterexample]] to a [[Universal (metaphysics)|universal]] claim, rather than denying the counterexample or rejecting the original universal claim, this fallacy modifies the subject of the assertion to exclude the specific case or others like it by rhetoric, without reference to any specific objective rule. ==Origin== The use of the term was advanced by [[United Kingdom|British]] philosopher [[Antony Flew]]: {{bquote|Imagine Hamish McDonald, a Scotsman, sitting down with his ''Glasgow Morning Herald'' and seeing an article about how the "[[Brighton]] Sex Maniac Strikes Again". Hamish is shocked and declares that "No Scotsman would do such a thing". The next day he sits down to read his ''Glasgow Morning Herald'' again; and, this time, finds an article about an [[Aberdeen]] man whose brutal actions make the Brighton sex maniac seem almost gentlemanly. This fact shows that Hamish was wrong in his opinion but is he going to admit this? Not likely. This time he says, "No ''true'' Scotsman would do such a thing".<ref>{{Citation | surname=Flew | given=Antony | title=Thinking About Thinking: Do I Sincerely Want to Be Right? | publisher=Collins Fontana | place=London | year=1975 | ISBN=978-0-00-633580-1}}</ref>}} When the statement "all ''A'' are ''B''" is qualified like this to exclude those ''A'' which are not ''B'', this is a form of [[begging the question]]; the conclusion is assumed by the definition of "true ''A''". ==Examples== A simple rendition of the fallacy would be:<ref>{{cite book | title=How the Mind Works | publisher=Hukilau | author=Pinker, Steven | authorlink=Steven Pinker | year=2003}}</ref> :Person A: "No Scotsman puts sugar on his porridge." :Person B: "I am Scottish, and I put sugar on my porridge." :Person A: "Then you are not a true Scotsman." An example of a political application of the fallacy could be in asserting that "no democracy starts a war", then distinguishing between mature or "true" democracies, which never start wars, and "emerging democracies", which may start them.<ref>[[David P. Goldman|Spengler]]. [http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Middle_East/HA31Ak01.html "No true Scotsman starts a war"], ''[[Asia Times Online]]'', Jan 31, 2006</ref> At issue is whether or not something labelled as an "emerging democracy" is actually a democracy or something in a different conceptual category. ==See also== {{col-begin}}{{col-break}} *[[Exception that proves the rule]] *[[Cognitive dissonance]] *[[Epistemic commitment]] *[[Equivocation]] *[[Euphemism]] {{col-break}} *[[Loaded language]] *[[Moving the goalposts]] *[[Persuasive definition]] *[[Reification (fallacy)]] *[[Special pleading]] {{col-end}} ==References== ;Notes {{reflist}} {{refimprove|date=May 2012}} <!--spacing--> {{Informal Fallacy}} [[Category:Informal fallacies]] [[Category:Verbal fallacies]] [[fa:اسکاتلندی واقعی نبودن]] [[fr:Aucun bon écossais]] [[ru:Неистинный шотландец]]
